true 834f07841be200105c01dd3cdc4bcbb8 not requested 2020-01-20 09:15:55 6816f79cc0a8016401c5a33be04be441 Objective

The goal for this induction task is to identify if you have a firewall class available within the CMDB to capture your Firewalls and their required attributes. You will also learn how to identify inherited properties within the CMDB, edit existing fields, and add new required fields.  

 

 Estimated Time To complete

2 hours

 

 Knowledge Required

CMDB core configuration. 

Review wiki for CMDB.

 

 Test Case

I. Find a CI Class for Firewalls

1. Click the gear icon next to the Logout button and toggle Tabbed forms to on. 

2. Navigate to System Definition > Tables.
 
3. Select Label and search for Network Gear. Select Network Gear table.
 
4. Scroll to Related Links and select Show Schema Map.
 
5. Uncheck Show referenced tables and Show referencing tables. Right-click the IP Firewall and select Focus on this table.
 
6. Expand the Network Gear, Hardware and Configuration Item Columns on the IP Firewall table by clicking on the + signs and check for an Owned By field and Version field. 
 
7. Notice there is an Owned by field within the Configuration Item column; however, there is no Version field. You will create the Version field in the next topic.  

 

 

II. Add Existing and New Fields to the Firewalls Form

1. Navigate to System Definition > Tables. Select Label and search for IP Firewall. Select the IP Firewall table.

2. Scroll to the Related Links and select Show Form.

3. Select Additional Actions > Configure > Form Design.  

4. In the left navigation pane, select the Fields tab and search for the Owned by field. Select the Owned by field in the left pane and drag it under the Asset field in the right pane.  

5. Select the Field Types tab in the left pane and search for String field. Select String field in the left pane and drag it under the Owned by field in the right pane.

6. Click the New String field and rename it to Version.  

7. Select the Version field. Click on the edit wheel and change the field name to u_version. Click Save on the top right of the forms designer and the close browser tab.  

8. Select Additional Actions on the IP Firewall form and select Reload form. Both the Owned by and Version fields should be visible.  

 

 

III. Add Firewalls to the Configuration Application

1. Right click the Configuration application in the left navigation pane and select Edit Application Menu. 

2. Select New Module button and complete the form as follows : 

   (1) Title : Firewalls

   (2) Order : 425

   (3) Table : IP Firewall [cmdb_ci_ip_firewall] 

   (4) View name : Firewalls

   (5) Click Submit.

 

 

IV. Import firewall data

1. Create a New Import Set

    (1) Navigate to System Import Sets > Load Data.

    (2) Create a New import set :

          Label: Firewall Import

          Table name: auto fills with u_firewall_import

          Choose File: firewalls.xls (you will find enclosed this file)

          Click Submit.

      (3) The screen should look like the example. Click Create transform map.  

  

     (4). Complete the form as follows.

              (Preselected) Source table: Firewall_import [u_firewall_import]

              Name: Firewall Import

              Target table: IP Firewall [cmdb_ci_ip_firewall]

              Select Auto Map Matching Fields.
                          •Coalesce fields identified in Step 4 tell the system which field to use as the unique. You can have multiple coalesce fields, but for this exercise:

                                      o Since the fields in the spreadsheet match the fields in the CMDB, the Auto map matching fields link is available.

                                      o If the fields did not match, you would need to use Mapping Assist. Click the Mapping Assist link to see the drag and drop UI for mapping fields. Click Cancel                                              when you are done.

              Coalesce : name = true

              Click Transform. 


              Be sure Firewall Import – cmdb_ci_ip_firewall is preselected then click Transform.  

 

 

V. Import firewall relationships 

1. Navigate to System Import Sets > Load Data.

2. Create a New import set table.

         Label: Firewall Relationships

        Table name: auto fills with u_firewall_relationships

        Choose File: firewall_host_relationships.xls  

3. The screen should look like the example. Click Create transform map.  

 

4. Complete the form as follows.

      (Preselected) Source table: [u_firewall_relationships]

      (1) Name: Firewall Relationships

      (2) Target table: CI Relationship [cmdb_rel_ci]

      (3) Select Auto map matching fields.

      (4 +5) Since there are no Auto Matching Fields, you must select Mapping Assist.  

 

 

 

5. Use the Drag and Drop Mapping Assist editor to complete the correct Field Map following the example. Click Save when finished mapping.  

 

 

 

 

6. On the Field Map related list, select New and complete the form as follows.

        (1) Map: Firewall Relationships

        (2) Use source script: Checked

        (3) Source script: answer = '1a9cb166f1571100a92eb60da2bce5c5'

        (4) Target field: Type  

 

7. Set Coalesce to True for all Target fields, then click Transform.  

 

 

VI. Create a Change and View  Business Impact  

1. Navigate to Change > New Change Request.

 

2. Complete the Change Request Form with the following:

      (1) Requested by: Tony Stark

      (2) Category: Network

      (3) Configuration Item: fw_prl_01

      (4) Short description and Description: Firewall requires firmware upgrade.

      (5) Assignment group: Network  

 

3. Right click the form header and select Save.  

 

 

4. Right click the form header again and select Refresh Impacted Services.  

 

 

5. The Impacted Services/CIs related list should look like the example.  

 

 

 

Trainee  Instructions

Trainee should propose the technical design and get approval from Coach before implementing the solution. After approval please implement it in the instance specified by the Coach using separate update set. Perform the unit testing before reporting task as completed to the Coach.

 

Coach Instructions

The configuration management database (CMDB) underpins all service management processes. This induction task teaches you how to get the most value out of it. Learn how to ensure you get good data into the CMDB and certify that it remains valid. Learn how to extend the CMDB, how to map service relationships and visualize dependencies, and use the new baseline feature introduces in our latest release.  Prerequisite: ServiceNow administration helpful, but not required.
